unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Degrees of Freedom and Statistical Significance
question_text: Lauren conducted a one-sample $t$ -test for a population mean and her results were found to be statistically significant at the $\alpha=0.05$ level. Later, she realized that she had calculated the $p$ -value using the wrong value for degrees of freedom, $\text{df}$ .  If the true $\text{df}$ should have been higher than the $\text{df}$ she had used in her calculation, would her results still be statistically significant?

choices.text: No, using a higher value for df df would result in a higher p p -value.
Maybe, using a higher value for df df would result in a higher p p -value, but the p p -value may still be less than 0.05 0.05 .
Maybe, using a higher value for df df would result in a lower p p -value, but the p p -value may then end up being too low for the results to be considered statistically significant.
Yes, using a higher value for df df would result in a lower p p -value.
It depends on whether Lauren was using a one-sided or two-sided alternative hypothesis.
